WRITING.TEXT: My anorexia was/ is comorbid with my OCD. Especially from a health OCD perspective. I became very concerned about nutrients and avoiding weight gain to minimize poor health effects. The ED was diagnosed and treated first. Putting some weight back on actually lessened the compulsions and anxiety around food. Pretty much weight restored now and some of the obsessions about food are still there but they really have gone down. I don't have to eat certain things in certain ways anymore. Currently, I'm working on my other health related anxieties. Feel free to message me if you want to talk/ have other questions. I'm pretty open.
Yes. 100%. Especially the part about "does a real schizophrenic say..." It's that kind of thinking that gets me caught in the OCD anxiety loop.

I have this too! Worry about personality disorders and schizophrenia in addition to the more common physical health concerns.
The mental health fears really screw with my mind. Oh, worried I have a mental health problem. Wait. Is that being self focused? Am I a narcissist? Etc.

WRITING.TITLE: I'm having a hard time.
WRITING.TEXT:
I came back from a trip where I allowed myself to enjoy things that scare me (bread, chocolate, etc). I could feel myself getting flabby. (This is probably just my brain but it's still disturbing). But now that I'm home, I'm having a hard time. I eat and I feel insanely guilty. It's unpleasant and also scary because if I were to relapse, I'm done. Fucking done. The recovery process is hard.
So basically I don't know what to do. I had like 800 calories of chocolate today (not bingey, it was a fancy desert) and I feel like absolute shit. I want to download my fitness pal again to try to control myself. I want to stop taking my Prozac. Fuck. Why is this happening again.

Thank you for the reminder. I don't want to remember the trip where I maintained a perfect diet and exercise regime and a perfect body. I want to remember having fun with my family and seeing new places.
I've thrown out all my scales so that won't be an issue luckily. And I made an appointment with my therapist Monday to help ensure that I transition back into the routine I had before the trip.

WRITING.TITLE: Traveling with my family and I can tell I'm gaining fat
WRITING.TEXT:
I've been eating so well. Trying things I've been scared of for over a year and trying to just generally enjoy the trip. It started out fine and I was able to handle it. Now I'm getting towards the end of the trip (2 weeks) and I can feel and see it collecting on my stomach. I don't like it at all. I can go through all the rational thought processes (it's not really noticeable, after starvation, regained weight goes to the stomach, etc). But at the end of the day, it still bothers me. I know rationally it's probably not much if any weight any ways because we've been active and moving the whole trip.
Anyway, my problem is that my ED wants me to go back to restricting when I get home. But I can't. Because if I relapse, I think I'm done. Getting better to this point was the hardest thing I have ever done and I don't think I could do it again.
I'm just frustrated. And tired of this shit.

This is the point I want to get to. I want to be able to tell people off like that while also bringing awareness to the vast array of ED symptoms. Unfortunately, I'm still at a point where I stutter and freeze and get embarrassed.

Not what you want to hear, but I really don't think running that race is safe for you. I'm sure it's really disappointing I have put in all that time and effort to train, but now is not the time for a race for you. Eating disorders are diseases and they suck. I'm glad you are getting help at residential. There will be plenty of time for races afterwards when you are healthy and can enjoy it completely for the right reason. Seeing you run a race while so sick would hurt your family.
No judgement, though, because I've totally been there. The exercise addiction part of my ED was the hardest to break.
South Park.

It must be a good week for peanut butter out of the jar! I worked on and conquered that fear a few days ago too. Way to go, though. It's amazing and rewarding to be able to look back and realize how far you've come. Never go back. :)
Seconding Fight Song. I wake up to this song every morning as my alarm and often listen to it during the day randomly to keep me going.

Yeah, this is for sure OCD. Such a sneaky monster. I think your best course of action is learning to accept the anxious uncertainty in your capability of accepting your emotions. The same way you fought the original obsessions. Obsessions don't have to be static. They often move from subject to subject through life.
It's the best for some people. I wouldn't stop taking it for anything as it has given me my life back, but different drugs work differently in different people.

Everyone reacts and metabolizes different meds differently. I might suggest talking to psych again and getting it switched. I actually experienced the opposite when I started fluoxetine. It leveled out pretty quickly through to a happy normal so to speak. Given you've had 2 months with little improvement, you might want to look into switching on to a different med or changing the dose. My side effects were worse at lower doses and got better (and decreased symptoms) as I made my way up in dosage.

I have a touch of this too. Part of my OCD is being convinced I am actually a horrible person who secretly wants to hurt everyone and destroy lives. I'm constantly checking my emotions to make sure I'm feeling the right thing at the right time. And overcompensating to prove my good intentions. So what you are feeling is very much in line with OCD symptoms. And you're not alone!
Finding a good therapist has been helpful for me. Right now I'm working on thought desensitization so basically when I get a bad thought stuck in my mind, I'm supposed to say it outlays a bunch of times really fast/ in a weird voice because it makes the concept more abstract. It's less believable in a weird voice and out loud. The goal is that this will eventually translate to what goes on in my head. I feel ridiculous even though it's just me alone in my car doing this, but it honestly helps. At least in the moment.

I for sure have days where it flares up. Usually it has to do with uncertainty and anxiety in another part of my life and my brain tries to control it with "making sure" I don't get develop chronic diseases like diabetes or heart disease or whatever (which is what my OCD is mostly about). I'm sure there are other things that trigger flare ups for me, but I'm still early in the process of learning how to handle my OCD, so it's still hard for me to say. Just wanted to let you know, that from my perspective anyway, it's really normal to have good days and bad days for symptoms.

Damn, I know this feeling all too well. I'm sure this isn't what you want to hear, but this isn't going to go away on its own. I suggest finding a therapist with some ED experience and working through it that way before it gets worse. PM me if you ever need to talk.
Your guidance counselor sounds like an amazing human being. It warms my heart to be reminded that such caring people exist. He's in a good place to work given his skill set it sounds like.

I definitely think you are developing disordered thoughts. I really encourage you to seize a moment of insight like this and reach out to someone in your life who can help you. It's a dangerous path to go down and it becomes harder and harder to break out and get help as you get more ill. One of many cruel ironies of ED.

Oh man, that's rough. I had to switch to an inpatient team when I did IP and partial, and the transition is hard. It can be good to get new opinions though. Like a variety of opinions from a variety of sources.
Don't worry. There are an insane number of checks and balances. And my work location has one of the lowest medication error rates in the country.

Going off that, do you have a therapist? He or she can meet with you and your mom together to hash things out and try to come up with a plan to best manage your nutrition.
All that being said, you are amazing for fighting through the ED story towards recovery.

Oh man, the being pulled different directions sucks. I had to be treated for anorexia first because it's hard to make progress in ERP when underweight as it made me really mentally unstable. As far as trauma goes, I can't speak specifically since I don't have any real serious trauma, but some of my friends from treatment have had success doing both at the same time. They found that their OCD is to control the thoughts and feelings the trauma brings up.
I'm sorry to hear you are having trouble finding a provider. That makes me so mad at this country. Ugh, the mental health insurance coverage in this country is deplorable. I've had luck with ERP just taking it one step at a time. It's a bitch to fight through and just feels overwhelming at times. I spent yesterday crying on my drive to over a fear of diabetes from bread, but it does eventually pass. Just know that and keep pushing. I'm super lucky in that I have an amazing mom, group of friends, and -most of all- therapist.
If you ever need to talk, I'm always willing to listen.

WRITING.TITLE: Pharmacy revenge- be a bitch, you can spend 20 minutes counting Tylenol
WRITING.TEXT:
I bore witness to the greatest petty revenge of my life at the major hospital pharmacy I work in.
The pharmacy techs pull the drugs. The more advanced techs (called checkers) have to check the work to ensure patient safety. They make sure each pill is the called for dose and the packaging is intact with a good expiration date Their job is made easier when whole, intact sleeves or boxes are used for high volume drugs like Senna or Tylenol.
One of the techs was pulling drugs. The bitchy checker kept going after her for not ordering the drugs in the specific way she desired. No other checker has this requirement. The tech got tired of being bitched at so when 200 Tylenol popped up, instead of pulling out 2 boxes, she found 200 loose Tylenol which forced the checker to scrutinize each individual pill. She stopped attacking the tech after that.
EDIT: TL;DR-- supervisor was nit picky to the extreme, was forced to carefully examine 200 individual capsules of Tylenol.

I just wanted to let you know how sorry I am to hear you're suffering. What a tough spot you are in life right now. I'm diagnosed with anorexia and OCD myself, and I know how bad the anorexia stuff can get when OCD is out of control. You sound like a very strong person; you have made it this far in life, and you will slowly get back on the recovery track and life will calm down for you. You are worth it and you deserve those better days.
Thanks for the support. God, it's so hard and make me feel like I'm doing the wrong thing constantly but I know logically that it's not. My therapist calls it scared but safe.

WRITING.TITLE: I ate some bread and now I'm terrified I will get diabetes
WRITING.TEXT: I'm not sure if this is more caused by my anorexia or my OCD, but they're probably super intertwined. Anyway, I did an exposure to white bread today and had a couple rolls (homemade) and now my anxiety is absolutely through the roof. I'm trying to get in to see my therapist this week, but I have to work during her open appointments. I just needed to rant and ask how others tolerate the extreme distress during ERP? I want to respond by exercising and not eating and such but I can't let myself do that. Why am I so convinced this bread will slowly kill me?

I had a nasty exercise compulsion. Honestly, what broke it for me was being physically prevented from exercising for a while. I was in IP for 8 days back in November and they didn't allow any exercise at all. While I was there, I met with a PT who specializes in exercise compulsions to come up with a safe exercise plan (mainly don't do cardio alone, stick to weight lifting until weight restored).
If you have OCD with your Ed like I do, having a structured plan really helped. Because I enjoy working out and always have, but having a plan with planned days off really helps. And a day off doesn't have to mean lying around all day- you can still walk or toss a ball with friends or something.

For me, the disobey has been the most effective but also the most challenging. It's so hard to do the opposite of what feels safe and just blindly leap in the opposite direction. It goes against human nature to avoid instinct even when one logically knows that it's wrong instinct.

I live even numbers or numbers divisible by 5. This part of my OCD was a huge issue with my anorexia because I wanted all of my foods to have these exact perfect calorie numbers and measuring things to get the numbers to work was exhausting.
Thanks for this. Great video and def something I needed to watch tonight after an intense, raw late night conversation with some friends.
Good point. But Philip would figure it out if she's trying to hide it from him. Much like Paige would probably be suspicious of Pastor Tim suddenly died.
Or, in the style of the show, took the rights at gun point.

I am wondering if Martha kills herself. She's had the gun for a while, but now she has a nice Valium prescription. It wouldn't take much for her to pop a few extra in a moment of feeling overwhelmed. Whether that be intentional or accidental.
It's the double edged sword of trying to keep her believing that no one gets hurt.

This is standard procedure for police. I knew someone who works in an at risk high school, and when an arrest cannot be made outside of class for whatever reason, they pull the student during class. And yes, they check for weapons- especially if the individual has been evading officers for a while.
They don't call names at spring graduation. The announce by group. So like L S students, cals students, etc. unless you are talking like med school, law school, and maybe masters and PhD.
Agree 100%. Tenure is a double edged sword for sure.
Mmmm, good thought!!
Thank you for letting me know!!!

Ahh, good catch. That wouldn't have bloody vomit as a symptom, but maybe what shes coughing up is the thick membrane associated with diphtheria.
Please excuse my microbiology nerd-ing.
I never knew shortly could be such an understatement.

The scene with Elizabeth's mother makes me wonder if she grew up near Sverdlovsk (now Yekaterinburg) during the anthrax accident. It would be consistent with the theme of biological warfare, and the bloody vomiting is a major symptom of gastrointestinal anthrax.
Elizabeth's love for her children is such a touching contrast to some of the cold way she conducts her business. I love it.
Stan poking around is going to give me a heart attack.

Same exact situation here. All it took was time. I'm almost weight restored now (slow gainer) but I got my period back finally and still workout. It just takes patience and more time than one might think. Your body has to trust you again.

I'm sorry to hear you are having a rough time! I think it is amazing that you have been able to keep yourself going 4 years after the hospital. That is amazing progress and a testament to your strength. I totally get the being hard to talk thing, but if you ever need an anonymous internet friend to vent to, message me. You'll get through this rough patch just like the others.

Adding to this wonderful post, continue to be a friend. Suggest fun activities to do and interact with the person like a normal friend would. You can tease them gently about non good/ appearance related things if that was part of your friendship before. Go places and do things that don't have to do with food.
Holy. Fucking. Shit.
Thank you for your kind words. It's so comforting to know I'm not alone. That's my favorite part of this subreddit. One can rant and have their feelings justified.

This is definitely true for me too. Thank you for reminding me that's usually the case. I guess it just caught me off guard by the intensity of the desire. It was like a light switch in my brain. It hasn't been this intense since like October when I did have a major relapse.

2015 graduate here. Changes are so hard and anxiety provoking. Graduating college is a major life transition. Do you have any plans for after college to focus on and look forward to? Additionally, do everything and hang out with everyone for your last little bit. Enjoy the present moment, because as you know, things will change. And when the change comes, take it bit by bit. It's scary and major but you can remain in contact with your friends. You have so much life a head of you and exciting new experiences. I'm sure the transition from high school to college was scary too, but you got through it and life was good. You'll get through to the graduated side and see that things, while different, aren't necessarily bad.
Add most Walgreens to that list too!

WRITING.TITLE: I want to relapse so fucking hard today. It hasn't been this bad in a few months.
WRITING.TEXT:
I know my weight. I get weighed at every therapy appointment on the same scale. I weighed myself at the gym today and it was 3 lbs higher than last Monday. Logically, I know I have not eaten that much and I'm on my period right now. But the ED has spent the day beating the shit out of me. I spent the afternoon crying and hating myself and eating spinach for dinner. And I don't know where this came from. I still have a few pounds to restore so it's not that. And I have been so so so happy these past few weeks. I started a new job and have been making new friends and am just loving life. Where the fuck did this desire to relapse come from and why am I miserable for no reason?!
Sorry, i just needed to rant.

There are biochem specific study abroad things where they put you in a lab and such. One is in Germany and the other option is um, I want to say Japan? But you should totally talk to the biochem advisors about this program. I wasn't a biochem major, but they talked about it in my biochem class and it sounded so cool.
